 16: 
 17: # "ctypedef" assigns a corresponding compile-time type to DTYPE_t. For
 18: # every type in the numpy module there's a corresponding compile-time
 19: # type with a _t-suffix.
 20: ctypedef np.int_t DTYPE_t
 21: 
 22: # "def" can type its arguments but not have a return type. The type of the
 23: # arguments for a "def" function is checked at run-time when entering the
 24: # function.
 25: #
 26: # The arrays f, g and h is typed as "np.ndarray" instances. The only effect
 27: # this has is to a) insert checks that the function arguments really are
 28: # NumPy arrays, and b) make some attribute access like f.shape[0] much
 29: # more efficient. (In this example this doesn't matter though.)
 30: cimport cython
 31: @cython.boundscheck(False) # turn off bounds-checking for entire function
 32: @cython.wraparound(False)  # turn off negative index wrapping for entire function

 39:     # The "cdef" keyword is also used within functions to type variables. It
 40:     # can only be used at the top indentation level (there are non-trivial
 41:     # problems with allowing them in other places, though we'd love to see
 42:     # good and thought out proposals for it).
 43:     #
 44:     # For the indices, the "int" type is used. This corresponds to a C int,
 45:     # other C types (like "unsigned int") could have been used instead.
 46:     # Purists could use "Py_ssize_t" which is the proper Python type for
 47:     # array indices.

+52:     cdef int smid = smax // 2

+53:     cdef int tmid = tmax // 2
